facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 185 to 187 of 1961 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 13, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 352 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 185 to 187 of 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 13, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 352 of 1957.

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 163 to 165 of 1959 under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: WITH Petitions Nos. 163 to 165 of 1959. Petitions Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by KAPUR, J. on November 20, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-The principal question raised in these appeals and petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the numberification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947, Bihar 19 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: The appeals relate to sales tax assessments for 1950-51, 1951-52, and 1952-53 with tax levied Rs. 28,866, Rs. 23,383, and Rs. 23,298 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the arguments in these appeals and petitions we announced our decision dismissing them with companyts and we number proceed to give our reasons for the same. The three appeals by special leave are brought by the assessee and relate to assessment of sales tax for three years, 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952-53 for which the amount of sales tax levied was Rs. 28,866, Rs. 23,383 and Rs. 23,298 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company and assessee, producer of sugar cane.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the three appeals the assessee companypany has filed three petitions under Art. 32 challenging the companystitutionality of the assessments. In this judgment the appellant and the petitioner is a private limited companypany and it will be termed appellant and the State of Bihar which is respondent will be termed the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeals to Deputy Commissioner of Commercial Taxes, then revision to Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an objection to the assessment and filed appeals to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial taxes and then a revision to the Board of Revenue and then at its instance the following question was referred by the Board of Revenue to the High Court for opinion- Whether sugar cane is a green vegetable within the meaning of item 6 of numberification No. 9884-FT dated 28-8-47 and as such exempt from taxation.

facts.text: Board of Revenue referred question to High Court: Whether sugar cane is a green vegetable within item 6 of notification No. 9884-FT dated 28-8-47 exempt from tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an objection to the assessment and filed appeals to the Deputy Commissioner of Commercial taxes and then a revision to the Board of Revenue and then at its instance the following question was referred by the Board of Revenue to the High Court for opinion- Whether sugar cane is a green vegetable within the meaning of item 6 of numberification No. 9884-FT dated 28-8-47 and as such exempt from taxation.

facts.text: Patna High Court held sugar cane not included in green vegetables.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant and held that sugar cane was number included in the term green vegetables and it is the companyrectness of that answer which has been canvassed before us.

facts.text: In Art. 32 petitions, appellant contended it is not a dealer under the Act as producer of sugar cane.

anchor.surface_text: In the petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution it was companytended that the appellant being a producer of sugar cane was number a dealer within the meaning of the Act and therefore numbertax was payable on sale of sugar cane by it.

facts.text: Exemption under s.6 Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947 via notification dated August 28, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The exemption under the Act is provided under s. 6 of the Act which, at the relevant time, was as follows- S. 6 No tax shall be payable under this Act on the sale of any goods or class of goods specified in this behalf by the State Government by numberification in the Official Gazette, subject to such companyditions as may be mentioned in the numberification Provided numbernotification shall be issued under this section without giving in the Official Gazette such previous numberice as the State Government may companysider reasonable, of its intention to issue such numberification.

facts.text: Notification No. 9884-FT dated August 28, 1947 issued under s.6 Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947 exempts green vegetables other than potatoes except in sealed containers.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6 of the Act the numberification relied upon was issued on August 28, 1947. This was numberification No. 9884-FT which was in the following terms- In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947  Bihar Act XIX of 1947 , and in supersession of the previous numberifications on the subject the Governor of Bihar is pleased to direct that numbertax shall be payable under the said Act on the sale of goods specified in the second companyumn of the schedule hereto annexed subject to the exceptions, if any, set out in the companyresponding entry in the third companyumn thereof. THE SCHEDULE Serial Description Exception subject to which the No. of goods. exemption has been allowed. 6 Green vegetables Except when sold in sealed other than pota- companytainers. toes.

facts.text: Principal question: whether sugar cane falls within green vegetables exempt from sales tax under notification dated August 28, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-The principal question raised in these appeals and petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the numberification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947, Bihar 19 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals and petitions with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised is that sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables in entry 6 of the Schedule and is therefore exempt from assessment to Sales tax.

facts.text: Definition of dealer in s.2(c) Bihar Sales Tax Act: any person who sells or supplies goods etc.

anchor.surface_text: The second question which was raised before us and which arises in the petitions under Art. 32 is that the appellant companypany is number a dealer within the meaning of the word as defined in s. 2 c  of the Act which is as follows- dealer means any person who sells or supplies any goods  including goods sold or supplied in the execution of a companytract  whether for companymission, remuneration or otherwise and includes any family or a Hindu joint family, the Government and any society club or association which sells or supplies goods to its members.

facts.text: Appellant contended amended definition of dealer in Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 applies only from April 1, 1950 for one year.

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued that the definition of the word dealer in the Act which was amended by Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 is applicable only for the financial year beginning April 1, 1950, and number for subsequent years and for that aid was sought from the preamble to the Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950.

facts.text: Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 amended definition of dealer in Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: That preamble is as follows- whereas it is expedient to amend the Bihar Sales Tax Act, 1947, and the Bihar Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1948, to levy a tax on passengers and goods carried by public service vehicles and public carries and to lay down rates on Sales Tax payable under Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947 to fix limit of taxable agricultural income to lay down rates of agricultural Income Tax Act and Super Tax chargeable under Bihar Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1948 for the financial year beginning on the 1st day of April 1950 and to make further provisions in companynection with the finance of this State of Bihar.

facts.text: No assent of President to Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 as per appellant contention.

anchor.surface_text: It was also submitted that the assent of the President was number given to the Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950.

facts.text: Court held sugar cane not a green vegetable based on common parlance, dictionary definitions as grass for sugar.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the meaning of the word vegetables sugar cane cannot fail within entry 6 which relates to green vegetables. In Websters dictionary sugar cane has been defined as a grass extensively grown in tropical and warm regions for its sugar and in Oxford dictionary it is defined as a tall peronnial grass cultivated in tropical and sub-tropical companyntries and forming the chief source of unmanufactured sugar. Therefore it cannot be said that sugar cane falls within the definition of the words green vegetables.

facts.text: Appellant is covered by wide definition of dealer under s.2(c).

anchor.surface_text: The words of this sub-section are very wide and companyer the case of the appellant and therefore this point is also without substance and must be rejected.

facts.text: Preamble to Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 does not limit amended definition to one year.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble cannot limit or change the meaning of the plain words of s.2 c  of the Act which apply to the case of the appellant and therefore the amended section is applicable to the present case. It is an erroneous approach to the question to say that because of the words for the financial year beginning on the first of April 1950 in the particular companytext in the preamble, the definition of the word dealer was amended only for one year Nothing has been shown indicating that section  2  i  of Bihar Annual Finance Act intended to effect a temporary amendment in the previous definition of the word dealer in cl c  of s.2 of the Act.

facts.text: Tax on sale of goods is within entry 54 State List, no need for President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion that submission is equally without force because tax on sale of goods is a matter entirely within entry 54 of the State List and the amendment made in the definition of the word dealer in the Act did number require the assent of the President.

facts.text: Court dismissed appeals and Art.32 petitions without merit with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the appeals and the petitions under Art. 32 are without merit and are therefore dismissed with companyts.

CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 185 to 187 of 1961. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 13, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 352 of 1957.
WITH Petitions Nos. 163 to 165 of 1959. Petitions Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

1961. November 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-The principal question raised in these appeals and petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the notification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947, Bihar 19 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

The principal question raised in these appeals and petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the notification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947, Bihar 19 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution it was contended that the appellant being a producer of sugar cane was not a dealer within the meaning of the Act and therefore no tax was payable on sale of sugar cane by it.
In our opinion the appeals and the petitions under Art. 32 are without merit and are therefore dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the notification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-The principal question raised in these appeals and petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution is whether sugar cane falls within the term green vegetables and is therefore exempt from sales tax under the exemption given by the notification dated August 28, 1947, issued under s. 6 of the Bihar Sales Tax Act 1947, Bihar 19 of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The second question which was raised before us and which arises in the petitions under Art. 32 is that the appellant company is not a dealer within the meaning of the word as defined in s. 2 c  of the Act which is as follows- dealer means any person who sells or supplies any goods  including goods sold or supplied in the execution of a contract  whether for commission, remuneration or otherwise and includes any family or a Hindu joint family, the Government and any society club or association which sells or supplies goods to its members.

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued that the definition of the word dealer in the Act which was amended by Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 is applicable only for the financial year beginning April 1, 1950, and not for subsequent years and for that aid was sought from the preamble to the Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion that submission is equally without force because tax on sale of goods is a matter entirely within entry 54 of the State List and the amendment made in the definition of the word dealer in the Act did not require the assent of the President.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not in common parlance as vegetables for table; follows own precedent; dictionary defines as grass

arguments.claim: sugar cane is fresh vegetable and exempt from sales tax under similar notification (citing State of Bombay v. R. S. Phadtare)

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention counsel for the appellant relied upon a judgment of the Bombay High Court, The State of Bombay v. R. S. Phadtare where it was held that sugar cane is fresh vegetable and is therefore exempt from sales tax under a similar notification issued under the Bombay Sales Tax Act. Changla C. J., there observed at page 496 as follows- In its plain and natural meaning a vegetable clearly is wide enough to cover sugar cane but what is urged by the Advocate General is that we must not give it that wide meaning but must give it the popular meaning as understood by people who deal in vegetables or eat vegetables, and it is urged that from that narrow and restricted point of view sugar cane is not vegetable. This is a taxing statue and if in favour of that construction which gives relief to the subject. That was exactly the approch of the Sales Tax Tribunal and in our opinion that approach was a very proper one.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rifications on the subject the Governor of Bihar is pleased to direct that numbertax shall be payable under the said Act on the sale of goods specifie

arguments.court_reasoning: Observation not in accord with this Court's opinion in Ramavatar Badriprasad; vegetables in taxing statutes mean common parlance kitchen garden produce for table

arguments.claim: sugar cane was not included in the term green vegetables

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant and held that sugar cane was not included in the term green vegetables and it is the correctness of that answer which has been canvassed before us.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: be issued under this section without giving in the Official Gazette such previous numberice as the State Government may companysider reasonable, of it

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees based on common parlance, precedent, dictionaries

arguments.claim: word vegetable in taxing statutes is to be understood as in common parlance i.e. denoting class of vegetables grown in a kitchen garden or in a farm and used for the table; sugar cane does not fall within green vegetables

anchor.surface_text: This observation is not in accord with the opinion given by this Court in Ramavatar Badriprasad v. Assistant Sales tax Officer, Akola in which under an almost identical entry it was held that betel leaves is not included in the term vegetables. After quoting with approval a passage from the judgment of the Nagpur High Court, Madhya Pradesh Pan Merchants Association v. State of Madhya Pradesh this Court said the word vegetable in taxing statutes is to be understood as in common parlance i.e. denoting class of vegetables which are grown in a kitchen garden or in a farm and are used for the table. If that is the meaning of the word vegetables sugar cane cannot fall within entry 6 which relates to green vegetables. In Websters dictionary sugar cane has been defined as a grass extensively grown in tropical and warm regions for its sugar and in Oxford dictionary it is defined as a tall perennial grass cultivated in tropical and sub-tropical countries and forming the chief source of unmanufactured sugar. Therefore it cannot be said that sugar cane falls within the definition of the words green vegetables.

arguments.claim: the appellant being a producer of sugar cane was not a dealer within the meaning of the Act and therefore no tax was payable on sale of sugar cane by it

anchor.surface_text: In the petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution it was contended that the appellant being a producer of sugar cane was not a dealer within the meaning of the Act and therefore no tax was payable on sale of sugar cane by it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f in favour of that companystruction which gives relief to the subject. That was exactly the approch of the Sales Tax Tribunal and in our opinion that

arguments.court_reasoning: Words of s.2(c) very wide and cover the case of the appellant

arguments.claim: definition of dealer covers any person who sells or supplies any goods including producer like appellant

anchor.surface_text: The second question which was raised before us and which arises in the petitions under Art. 32 is that the appellant company is not a dealer within the meaning of the word as defined in s. 2 c of the Act which is as follows- dealer means any person who sells or supplies any goods including goods sold or supplied in the execution of a contract whether for commission, remuneration or otherwise and includes any family or a Hindu joint family, the Government and any society club or association which sells or supplies goods to its members. The words of this sub-section are very wide and cover the case of the appellant and therefore this point is also without substance and must be rejected.

arguments.claim: definition of dealer amended by Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 applicable only for financial year beginning April 1, 1950, not subsequent years (per preamble)

anchor.surface_text: But it was argued that the definition of the word dealer in the Act which was amended by Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950 is applicable only for the financial year beginning April 1, 1950, and not for subsequent years and for that aid was sought from the preamble to the Bihar Annual Finance Act 1950.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rown in tropical and warm regions for its sugar and in Oxford dictionary it is defined as a tall peronnial grass cultivated in tropical and sub-tropic

arguments.court_reasoning: Preamble cannot limit plain words of s.2(c); nothing indicates temporary amendment

arguments.claim: preamble does not limit amended definition of dealer to one year; plain words apply

anchor.surface_text: The preamble cannot limit or change the meaning of the plain words of s.2 c of the Act which apply to the case of the appellant and therefore the amended section is applicable to the present case. It is an erroneous approach to the question to say that because of the words for the financial year beginning on the first of April 1950 in the particular context in the preamble, the definition of the word dealer was amended only for one year Nothing has been shown indicating that section 2 i of Bihar Annual Finance Act intended to effect a temporary amendment in the previous definition of the word dealer in cl c of s.2 of the Act.

Therefore it cannot be said that sugar cane falls within the definition of the words green vegetables.

It is an erroneous approach to the question to say that because of the words for the financial year beginning on the first of April 1950 in the particular companytext in the preamble, the definition of the word dealer was amended only for one year Nothing has been shown indicating that section  2  i  of Bihar Annual Finance Act intended to effect a temporary amendment in the previous definition of the word dealer in cl c  of s.2 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the arguments in these appeals and petitions we announced our decision dismissing them with costs and we now proceed to give our reasons for the same.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals by special leave and petitions under Article 32 dismissed; sugar cane held not to be green vegetable exempt from sales tax; appellant held to be a dealer liable to sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: If that is the meaning of the word vegetables sugar cane cannot fail within entry 6 which relates to green vegetables. In Websters dictionary sugar cane has been defined as a grass extensively grown in tropical and warm regions for its sugar and in Oxford dictionary it is defined as a tall peronnial grass cultivated in tropical and sub-tropical companyntries and forming the chief source of unmanufactured sugar. Therefore it cannot be said that sugar cane falls within the definition of the words green vegetables.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble cannot limit or change the meaning of the plain words of s.2 c  of the Act which apply to the case of the appellant and therefore the amended section is applicable to the present case. It is an erroneous approach to the question to say that because of the words for the financial year beginning on the first of April 1950 in the particular companytext in the preamble, the definition of the word dealer was amended only for one year Nothing has been shown indicating that section  2  i  of Bihar Annual Finance Act intended to effect a temporary amendment in the previous definition of the word dealer in cl c  of s.2 of the Act.
